ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed more critical thinking skills and learned how to better apply things I have learned in other classes.

- Systems modeling (cells and signaling pathways)
- Applications of signaling models in real world situations (ie. drug delivery)
biotransport (diffusion, convection, reactions, etc.) and kinetics (rates of reaction, etc.)

Knowledge: I learned a lot about mathematical modeling as it relates to the concepts I have learned in MB&B 300. Also, I became more proficient in MATLAB.

Skills: How to simplify complicated-looking systems to a set of differential equations or another mathematical model.

Insights: Biomedical engineering is very broad, and mathematical models can be applied to anything if you really try hard enough!
I learned how to model biological systems and the assumptions and considerations scientists take when studying biological systems.

- explored models of biological transport and biochemical reaction processes. 
- derived theoretical equations to mathematically describe biological processes, and critically analyze these models. 
- designed models to create a biological sensor
Biochemical interactions, thermodynamics, binding and enzyme kinetics, modeling diffusion and transport of molecules in the body
This course taught me how to solve kinetic and biotransport problems in biomedical engineering.
This course was a good survey of modeling biological systems

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Great professor (KMJ) who was very clear in her lectures and had an incredibly well thought-out outline for the topics. The sequential order made perfect sense to me and I felt like the test material was fair -- all extensions of concepts we went over in class.
Weaknesses: While I loved the real-world applications of the project, I do believe it was a bit ambiguous for some parts (ie. calculating response magnitude).
Though the course covers two very separate topics (transport and kinetics), Professor Miller-Jensen does a good job of bridging the topics to make the information and connection easier to understand.

Strengths: KMJ is a great lecturer, and the material is very interesting. The class is not easy by any means, but Prof. Miller-Jensen really does a great job at simplifying seemingly impossible models into digestible solutions. Also, the project presented a very nice break from the P-set routine, and I think I was able to learn better through the project.

Weaknesses: Since lecture was on zoom, there was little incentive to actually show up to class, necessarily leading to a lot of review outside of class. This may not be a bad thing, but perhaps more can be done to incentivize people to show up to class. Also, section was not very helpful.

Strength: I liked the teaching 
Weakness: The wording of problems on PSETs was sometimes confusing and convoluted.

Strengths: KMJ is an incredible professor. She lectures clearly and welcomes discussion/questions. She experimented with breakout rooms, polls, etc.

Weaknesses: The class itself is very equation-heavy (which makes it confusing for students taking this course concurrently with biosignals and images). The PSET questions are also long and very involved. The project was frustrating and not super helpful for learning the material.
The course was strong in that the instructor is good at explaining how to solve problems.
More prompt feedback on assignments would have been nice, also the chance to ask questions about previous assignments

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I loved the breakout room discussions and the few breaks KMJ incorporated towards the end of the semester!

The virtual lecture format was successful. Screen share allowed us to simulate a class room chalk board setting. We were able to take notes as Professor Miller-Jensen wrote them on her iPad. Discussion sections weren't as successful if the TA didn't have the same technology, but material review and PSET questions were still covered.
The adaptation of exams to be open for a 24-hour period was a great accommodation to the uncertainties of the COVID-19 pandemic.
Practices: I liked being able to rewatch lectures. I didn't love breakout rooms.
Recorded lectures were helpful for learning.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I loved this class and the assignments associated with it!

Yes! Besides being a requirement for BME majors, the course is definitely challenging yet rewarding in the end. KMJ is an excellent lecturer who explains everything very clearly and puts in the effort to make sure that anything unclear is resolved! Definitely very applicational in the sense that the material we learned can be applied in various areas of the world today (ie. COVID and drug delivery).
I'd recommend it to those who want to understand the math/equations behind biological processes and enjoy engineering applications to biology.

The course is a difficult one, and sometimes the material might not come across as the most interesting. However, I still enjoyed the class. KMJ is a great lecturer and probably one of the coolest professors at Yale, and you do learn a lot about drug delivery kinetics and transport. If you are a premed who has taken biochemistry and likes quantitative analysis, then this might be the class for you if you are up for the challenge.
I'm not sure I would recommend this class unless you have specific interests in using math models to describe a biotransport system
Depends. The PSETs are long and the material is quite heavy, but it would be a great course to cred/d/fail. The professor is wonderful, as well.
I would recommend this class to all BME students who wants to learn how to solve biomedical problems.
